Notice how Bruni only selects TFA or Reformers to interview? How about an interview with Carol Burris, a NY principal, who has been writing extensively on the problems with these so-called Reforms and how they effect the students in her school. Or how about Diane Ravitch?
To bring up Michael Winerip again, he wrote a thoughtful column about an evaluation system used in Montgomery County, Md. called PAR--Peer Assistance Review. Perhaps if Johnston had done is homework, he would have found an evaluation system that values teachers and the job they do without the loss of due process. Under PAR teachers are either fired, leave on their own accord, or are given an extra year of staff development. It is a good way to separate the good from the bad, but many districts can't use it because RTTT funding is solely based on evaluating teachers using test scores. Montgomery County decided they wanted to keep their evaluation system and therefore didn't receive any government funding. Montgomery County was the first to call for a moratorium on high-stakes testing until the Common Core could be implemented correctly. Now that seems to be the call around the Nation.
Tenure does not protect teachers from yelling at their principals. That's insubordination and leads to dismissal. Tenure gives the teacher the right to question mandates that are not working for their students. Tenure gives teachers the right not to fear retribution for asking questions.
You'd need a FOIA request to answer that question.

Agreed. Two Boys was fantastic, and the only interesting, daring opera on the season last year. And the hall was packed with the youngest audience I've ever seen at the Met. I've heard the classics, I want to hear something new and be challenged as a smart listener and viewer. I don't want frivolous entertainment. My criticism is that the Met doesn't do MORE new works and MORE new productions--that's the stuff that keeps opera interesting. And thanks to the unions for deciding that their high salaries are worth more than the music and productions for audiences, I'm doubtful the Met will want to take the risk. The musicians barely took cuts...3.5%?! That basically means they don't get a raise in the next four years. What a negotiation, particularly for the highest paid musicians in the industry. (Who are paid a lot more than most of the administration, just fyi. The administration is more than just Peter Gelb.) Thanks, but I'll go support all the amazingly talented musicians who play at places like Roulette, BAM, the Kitchen, the Stone, and other interesting venues, who clearly put art above money-making. And no, higher salary does not equal higher quality, definitely not here in NYC.
I disagree. the Nose and Nixon in China have been high points for some of us devotees of HD on the W Coast, even if ot Menes era at 9 am...

Several provincial responses from those who go to The Met.
In case you can not read, I am referring to the digital broadcasts to local theaters. I have heard that theaters in LA in some areas do get full houses, but not here. As I said, opera goers here want to see the more traditional ones, which they have never had the chance to see.

As I have stated previously there are many of us who go to the digital broadcasts.

At times the theaters are almost empty, but this season shows a real good selection. Unfortunately there are some that are not being shown that would bring in more viewers.
Don Carlo
La Traviata
Lucia
and
Aida

These are known to the fans here, and almost any Verdi draws good attendance.
Most people in my area do not get a chance to see an opera at The Met, or if they do,it has only been one or two productions. You have to be quite well off to just fly to New York to see an opera. it means at least two night lodging, and the average crowd does not have the finances to be constantly doing so.

They do not go to productions such as "The Nose" "Nixon in China" or other modern productions.
Gelb has brought us these performances, and they can be capitalized on.

Unlike Bing who took away many great performers from us like Helen Trauble, and Robert Merrill among others, Gelb has presented some very good American ones. DiDonato is an SF favorite, as is Patricia Racette. They may not be Sutherland's or a Callas, but they give good performances.

For those of us confined to the western wilderness, it looks like a good season.

As a cardiologist, using these medications daily, I feel the need to discuss this issue. While true there are home INR moniteering devices, only medicare will cover the costs. Younger patients, non-medicare age, are not covered and often the older patients, refuse to do home testing.
While there are certainly bleeding issues with any anti-coagulant, there still does not exist a medical trial showing increased incidence of bleeding using a new, novel anti-coagulant versus coumadin. This has been lawyer driven, as noted by the obscene trolling for patients in the newspapers and late night television commercials.

I used to work in a Coumadin clinic. We used fingerstick machines to check INRs similar to the at home devices. The problem is that these machines are sensitive to movement, temperature, etc. Many of them also need controls run every day to be sure they are functioning properly. They are not as easy to maintain in a home as you would think.

> While true there are home INR moniteering devices, only medicare will cover the costs.

Not true. I'm not (yet) of Medicare age, and my insurance covered it.

However -- and the rep who brought me the meter didn't talk about this -- the home machine needs "calibration" comparing to lab results. The difference is pretty consistent, but important to know, and factor in.
There are home INR test kits. Why do not more doctors recommend their use for patients on warfarin rather than office visits and a more expensive lab test?
